title: Wrong date format in s3 headers
body:
<!--

We understand you are having a problem with rclone; we want to help you with that!

**STOP and READ**
**YOUR POST WILL BE REMOVED IF IT IS LOW QUALITY**:
Please show the effort you've put into solving the problem and please be specific.
People are volunteering their time to help! Low effort posts are not likely to get good answers!

If you think you might have found a bug, try to replicate it with the latest beta (or stable).
The update instructions are available at https://rclone.org/commands/rclone_selfupdate/

If you can still replicate it or just got a question then please use the rclone forum:

    https://forum.rclone.org/

for a quick response instead of filing an issue on this repo.

If nothing else helps, then please fill in the info below which helps us help you.

**DO NOT REDACT** any information except passwords/keys/personal info.

You should use 3 backticks to begin and end your paste to make it readable.

Make sure to include a log obtained with '-vv'.

You can also use '-vv --log-file bug.log' and a service such as https://pastebin.com or https://gist.github.com/

Thank you

The Rclone Developers

-->

#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
If I serve via s3 rclone seems to use an invalid format for at least the `Last-Modified` header.

To test I created a directory `test` and file `file` in it. I set the file to a specific last-accessed and last-modified date using `touch -amt 202412092222 file`:
```bash
ls -la
drwxr-xr-x cubic cubic 60 B Sat Dec 21 23:07:20 2024 ÔÑï .
drwxr-xr-x cubic cubic 60 B Sat Dec 21 23:07:13 2024 ÔÑï ..
.rw-r--r-- cubic cubic  0 B Mon Dec  9 22:22:00 2024 ÔÄñ file
```

If I now serve the file via http from the directory `test` using `rclone serve http test` I get:
```bash
curl --head localhost:8080/file

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Content-Length: 0
Last-Modified: Mon, 09 Dec 2024 21:22:00 GMT
Server: rclone/v1.68.2
Date: Sat, 21 Dec 2024 22:11:46 GMT
```

Now if I serve the directory `test` as a bucket with the file `file` in it using `rclone serve s3 .` I get:
```bash
curl --head localhost:8080/test/file

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Accept, Accept-Encoding, Authorization, Content-Disposition, Content-Length, Content-Type, X-Amz-Date, X-Amz-User-Agent, X-CSRF-Token, x-amz-acl, x-amz-content-sha256, x-amz-meta-filename, x-amz-meta-from, x-amz-meta-private, x-amz-meta-to, x-amz-security-token
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: POST, GET, OPTIONS, PUT, DELETE, HEAD
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Access-Control-Expose-Headers: ETag
Content-Length: 0
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
Etag: "d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e"
Last-Modified: Mon, 9 Dec 2024 22:22:00 GMT
Server: AmazonS3
X-Amz-Id-2: RUNEMjk5NzlFQ0MyQkM2OEVDRDI5OTc5RUNDMkJDNjhFQ0QyOTk3OUVDQzJCQzY4RUNEMjk5NzlFQ0MyQkM2OA==
X-Amz-Request-Id: ECD29979ECC2BC68
Date: Sat, 21 Dec 2024 22:08:03 GMT
```

There are two things to note: The `Last-Modified` header from the s3 server has the value `Mon, 9 Dec 2024 22:22:00 GMT`. This is invalid, as the date, as far as I understand the corresponding RFC and [Mozilla](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Last-Modified), must be in a two-digit representation (same as the http server sends). It also differs from the http response by one hour. My time zone is GMT+1, it seems to use the local time and GMT inconsistently.

I came across this bug by using pgBackRest to backup my postgres cluster against s3 provided by rclone and it failed with `ERROR: [029]: invalid month 'ec '` during the debug. After looking through the debug log for the string I discovered that it refers to the cut off `Dec` month. It probably reads the date header in fixed offsets which always expect the date to be 2 digits long.


#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)
1.68.2


#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (e.g. Windows 7, 64 bit)
Linux 64 bit


#### Which cloud storage system are you using? (e.g. Google Drive)
Tested with local and SFTP backends


#### The command you were trying to run (e.g. `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
rclone serve s3 .


#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (e.g. output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
Does not apply


<!--- Please keep the note below for others who read your bug report. -->

#### How to use GitHub

* Please use the üëç [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.
